We have a conditional statement "If Lisa bought the red shirt, then Mark bought the blue shirt", which can be represented as "P → Q", where P is "Lisa bought the red shirt" and Q is "Mark bought the blue shirt". We are also given that "Mark bought the blue shirt", which is Q.

To conclude "Lisa bought the red shirt" (P), we need to determine if the given statements allow us to infer P. In a conditional statement, if Q is true, it does not necessarily mean that P is true. This is because the conditional statement only guarantees that if P is true, then Q must be true, but it does not provide any information about the converse.

In this case, we know that Q is true, but we cannot conclude that P is true solely based on this information. There might be other reasons why Mark bought the blue shirt, unrelated to Lisa buying the red shirt.
